column12: Radar detector for pre-impact airbag triggering
column15: CROSBY ROBERT GLENN II

column12: RADAR DETECTOR FOR PRE-IMPACT AIRBAG TRIGGERING
column13: A pulsed radar detector to be used for airbag triggering prior to a collision between a vehicle on a roadway and an impacting target object, has sets of transmitters (10) and receivers (20) separately disposed on the side of a vehicle so as to create a bistatic antenna pattern. The transmitting antennae are mounted relative to receiving antennae so as to control the amount of direct radiation from each transmitter antenna (11) and said receiver antenna (21) so as to create a modulation of a received target signal. A signal processor (30) determines the period of the modulation in order to obtain a measure of target velocity. The amplitude of the modulation is determined so as to have a measure of relative target size. Using this data, a computer (31) continuously calculates the predicted time and point of impact in order to initiate the release of an airbag at a predetermined time before impact between said object and the side of the vehicle.
column15: CROSBY ROBERT GLENN II

column12: IMPLEMENTATION OF HIGH EFFICIENCY BATTERY CHARGER FOR ELECTRONIC DEVICES
column13: A power converter including a buck converter to receive input power and set operating voltages of the power converter, a current sensing circuit to determine an input current of the power converter, a charge pump circuit to store charge delivered by the voltage regulation circuit and output to a load and to a battery pack a current larger than the input current, and a battery pack controller to control switching and provide feedback within the power converter.
column15: CROSBY ROBERT GLENN II;;CHRISTIAANS PETER

column12: IMPLEMENTATION OF HIGH EFFICIENCY BATTERY CHARGER FOR ELECTRONIC DEVICES

column12: METHOD AND SYSTEM FOR CHARGING/DISCHARGING A BATTERY
column13: Embodiments of methods for charging/discharging a battery and DC/DC converter devices for charging/discharging a battery are described. In one embodiment, a method for charging/discharging a battery involves conveying energy from a direct current (DC) power source to the battery through a DC/DC converter device and conveying energy from the battery to the DC power source through the DC/DC converter device. Other embodiments are also described.

column12: AUTOMATIC TUNING OF RESONANCE-BASED WIRELESS CHARGING RECEIVER
column15: CROSBY ROBERT GLENN LL;;CHRISTIAANS PETER;;WU QIONG

column12: AUTOMATIC TUNING OF RESONANCE-BASED WIRELESS CHARGING RECEIVER
column13: A wireless charging receiver operates on a resonance principle and includes an impedance matching circuit coupled between an antenna and a rectifier circuit. The impedance matching circuit has both series-connected and parallel-connected capacitors. At least one of the capacitors is a tunable variable capacitor. A method is provided for automatically adjusting a capacitance value of the at least one variable capacitor based on an error voltage between a target rectifier voltage and a measured rectifier voltage. Automatically adjusting the antenna impedance of the receiver provides for improved power transfer efficiency for changing operating conditions. In one embodiment, one or more of the parallel-connected capacitors are variable capacitors. In another embodiment, one or more of the series-connected capacitors are variable capacitors.
column15: CROSBY ROBERT GLENN LL;;CHRISTIAANS PETER;;WU QIONG

column12: LOAD CURRENT MEASUREMENT
column13: In an example embodiment, an apparatus includes a bridge rectifier circuit having branches between the AC and DC nodes formed by a set of transistors. A load current measurement circuit includes a current-controlled current source coupled to the bridge rectifier circuit. The current control current source is configured to generate a mirrored current that is a scaled version of a current through at least one of the set of transistors. A current integration circuit is configured to integrate the mirrored current by charging a capacitor with the scaled current in a first mode and discharging the capacitor in a second mode. A sample and hold circuit is configured to set an output node to a voltage equal to a voltage stored by the capacitor in response to the current integration circuit entering the second mode and prior to the discharge of the capacitor.
column15: CHRISTIAANS PETER;;CROSBY II ROBERT GLENN;;ZHAN FU CHUN

column12: Load current measurement
column13: According to the embodiment, equipment comprises a bridge rectifier circuit which is provided with a branch which is arranged between AC nodes and DC nodes and formed by a transistor set; and a load current measurement circuit which comprises a current controlled current source, a current integral circuit and a sampling and holding circuit. The current controlled current source is coupled with the bridge rectifier circuit, wherein the current controlled current source is configured for generating image current, and the image current is the zoomed version of at least one current passing through the transistor set. The current integral circuit is configured for using the zoomed current to charge a capacitor under a first mode and discharge to the capacitor under a second mode and integrating to the image current. The sampling and holding circuit is configured for responding to the current integral circuit to enter the second mode and setting an output node into the voltage equal to the stored voltage of the capacitor before discharging of the capacitor.
column15: FU CHUN ZHAN;;ROBERT GLENN II CROSBY;;PETER CHRISTIAANS PETER

column12: METHOD FOR ENHANCING BIOAVAILABILITY OF BETA-CAROTENE
column15: HECKERT DAVID CLINTON;;MEHANSHO HAILE;;HUDEPOHL GLENN RICHARD;;CROSBY SAMUEL JR

column12: METODO PARA MEJORAR LA ABSORCION Y BIODISPONIBILIDAD DE BETA-CAROTENO.
column13: Se describe un método para mejorar la absorción de ß-caroteno en animales y seres humanos administrando una bebida que comprende: (a) de aproximadamente 0.05 a aproximadamente 0.3 de calcio; (b) por lo menos 0.0004 de ß-caroteno; (c) de aproximadamente 0.5 a aproximadamente 60 de edulcorante; (d) por lo menos 0.005 de sabor; y (e) el resto siendo agua. La bebida puede contener vitaminas C, A, B, D y E. La bebida debe estar esencialmente libre de fierro y metales que ocasionen la degradación de las vitaminas. Preferiblemente, la bebida contiene gomas y espesantes.
column15: CROSBY SAMUEL JR;;HECKERT DAVID CLINTON;;MEHANSHO HAILE;;HUDEPOHL GLENN RICHARD

column12: METHOD FOR ENHANCING BIOAVAILABILITY OF BETA-CAROTENE
column13: A method for enhancing β-carotene absorption in animals and humans by administering a beverage comprising: (a) from about 0.05 % to about 0.3 % calcium; (b) at least 0.0004 % of β-carotene; (c) about 0.5 % to about 60 % sweetener; (d) at least 0.005 % flavor; and (e) the remainder being water is disclosed. The beverage can contain vitamin C, A, B, D and E. The beverage must be essentially free of iron and metals which cause vitamin degradation. Preferably the beverage contains gums or thickeners.
column15: HECKERT DAVID CLINTON;;MEHANSHO HAILE;;HUDEPOHL GLENN RICHARD;;CROSBY SAMUEL JR

column12: HYBRID PHOSPHOINOSITIDE PHOSPHOLIPIDS: COMPOSITIONS AND USES
column15: PRESTWICH GLENN;;RZEPECKI PIOTR W;;FERGUSON COLIN G;;NEILSEN PAUL O;;BRANCH ANGIE;;CROSBY LEE R

column12: HYBRID PHOSPHOINOSITIDE PHOSPHOLIPIDS: COMPOSITIONS AND USES
column13: The methods and compositions disclosed synthesis of a novel class of 'two-headed' phospholipid-phosphoinositide hybrids possessing a carbon backbone, such as 2,3-diacylthreitol, erythritol or a synthetic module. The second phospholipid head group allows introduction of a biochemical or chemical moiety in a position orthogonal in space to those occupied by the phosphoinositide head group and the two acyl chains. The diacyl moieties allow for the incorporation of Pea-PIP2 into a lipid bilayer, while the Ptdlns(4,5)P2 moiety in the aqueous layer is specifically recognized by lipid binding proteins. In alternative embodiments of the invention, reporters, for example biotin, fluorophores and/or spin labels, are attached to the free amino group of the head groups of such molecules to specifically target the reporters to the lipid-water interface. Figure (1) illustrates (at c) an exemplary hybrid lipid of the present invention that possess a phosphatidylethanolamine (PE, or Pea) head group at the 1-position and a Ptdlns(4, 5)P2 head group at the 4-position.
column14: UNIV UTAH RES FOUND;;PRESTWICH GLENN;;RZEPECKI PIOTR W;;FERGUSON COLIN G;;NEILSEN PAUL O;;BRANCH ANGIE;;CROSBY LEE R

column12: Hybrid phosphoinositide phospholipids: compositions and uses
column13: The methods and compositions disclosed herein concern the synthesis of a novel class of “two-headed” phospholipid-phosphoinositide hybrids possessing a carbon backbone, such as 2,3-diacylthreitol, erythritol or a synthetic module. The second phospholipid head group allows introduction of a biochemical or chemical moiety in a position orthogonal in space to those occupied by the phosphoinositide head group and the two acyl chains. The diacyl moieties allow for the incorporation of Pea-PIP 2 into a lipid bilayer, while the Ptdlns(4,5)P 2 moiety in the aqueous layer is specifically recognized by lipid binding proteins. In alternative embodiments of the invention, reporters, for example biotin, fluorophores and/or spin labels, are attached to the free amino group of the head groups of such molecules to specifically target the reporters to the lipid-water interface.

column12: INVERTED BOTTLE DISPENSING SYSTEMS AND METHODS
column13: A dispensing system that includes a bottle, a valve cap, a dosing cap. The bottle includes a side wall having at least a portion that is flexible. The valve cap regulates the dispensing of a flowable product from bottle into the dosing cap. In particular, flowable product may be dispensed from the bottle into the dosing cap when the dispensing system is in an inverted position and while the dosing cap is attached to valve cap. The valve cap and the dosing cap may support the dispensing system in the inverted position.

column12: Inverted Bottle Dispensing Systems and Methods
column13: A dispensing system that includes a bottle, a valve cap, a dosing cap. The bottle includes a side wall having at least a portion that is flexible. The valve cap regulates the dispensing of a flowable product from bottle into the dosing cap. In particular, flowable product may be dispensed from the bottle into the dosing cap when the dispensing system is in an inverted position and while the dosing cap is attached to valve cap. The valve cap and the dosing cap may support the dispensing system in the inverted position.
